section.title: Enabling Default Backups of the Control Plane to an SSH Target
section.para: This topic describes how you can set up an external server as a backup server in case you lose access to your cloud servers that store the default backups.

section.title: Default Backup and Restore
section.para: As part of the installation procedure in &productname;, automatic backup/restore jobs are set up to back up to Swift via the Freezer scheduler component of the backup and restore service. The backup jobs perform scheduled backups of &productname; control plane data (files/directories/db). The restore jobs can be used to restore appropriate control plane data. Additional automatic jobs can be added to backup/restore from the secure shell (SSH) server that you set up/designate. It is recommended that you set up SSH backups so that in the event that you lose all of your control plane nodes at once, you have a backup on remote servers that you can use to restore the control plane nodes. Note that you do not have to restore from the SSH location if only one or two control plane nodes are lost. In that case, they can be recovered from the data on the remaining control plane node following the restore procedures in . That document also explains how to recover using your remote server SSH backups.
While control plane backups to Swift are set up automatically, you must use the following procedure to set up SSH backups.

section.title: Setting up SSH backups
section.para: By default, during &product; deployment, backup jobs are automatically deployed to Swift, the MySQL database, the &lcm;, and Swift rings. Restore jobs are also deployed for convenience. It is more secure to store those backups also outside of the &productname; infrastructure. If you provide all the values required in the following file, jobs will also be deployed to backup and restore to/from an SSH server of your choice:

section.title: Backing up your &productname; control plane to an SSH server
section.para: You must provide the following connection information to this server:

listitem.para: The SSH server's IP address
The SSH server's port to connect to (usually port 22). You may want to confirm how to open the port on the &productname; firewall.
The user to connect to the SSH server as
The SSH private key authorized to connect to that user (see below for details of how to set up one if it is not already done)
The directory where you wish to store the backup on that server

section.para: There is a strict policy of firewalling deployed with &productname;. If you use a non-standard SSH port, you may need to specifically open it by using the following process:

section.title: Securing your SSH backup server
section.para: You can do the following to harden an SSH server (these techniques are well documented on the internet):

listitem.para: Disable root login
Move SSH to a non-default port (that is, something other than 22)
Disable password login (only allow RSA keys)
Disable SSH v1
Authorize Secure File Transfer Protocol (SFTP) only for that user (disable SSH shell)
Firewall SSH traffic to ensure it comes from the &productname; address range
Install a Fail2Ban solution
Restrict users that are allowed to SSH

section.para: Remove the key pair generated earlier on the backup server: the only thing needed is the .ssh/authorized_keys. You can remove the .ssh/id_rsa and .ssh/id_rsa.pub files. Be sure to save a backup of them somewhere.
